Regional Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 40691 
December 2007 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Technical Assistance for Twelfth Agriculture and 
Natural Resources Research at International 
Agricultural Research Centers 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ANR  –  agriculture and natural resources 
  ANRR  –  agriculture and natural resources research 
  CGIAR  –  Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  EA  –  executing agency 
  IA  –  implementing agency 
  IARC  –  international agricultural research center 
  ICARDA  –  International Center for Agricultural Research in the Dry Areas 
  ICRISAT  –  International Crops Research Institute for the Semi-Arid Tropics 
  IFPRI  –  International Food Policy Research Institute 
  NARS  –  national agricultural research system 
  PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
  RETA  –  regional technical assistance 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Agriculture and natural resources 
Subsector  –  Agriculture sector development  
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth, environmental sustainability, regional 
cooperation 
Subthemes  –  Developing rural areas, natural resources conservation, sharing 
information and knowledge 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
Vice President  C. Lawrence Greenwood, Jr., Operations 2 
Director General  H. Satish Rao, East Asia Department (EARD) 
Director  K. Kannan, Agriculture, Environment, and Natural Resources Division, EARD 
   
Team leader  T. Lin, Natural Resources Economist, EARD 
Team member  C. Carreon, Associate Project Analyst, EARD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Since the adoption of the agriculture and natural resources research (ANRR) policy 
paper in 1995, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has supported the Consultative Group on 
International  Agricultural  Research  (CGIAR)  centers  and  other  non-CGIAR  international 
agricultural research centers (IARCs)1 through an annual regional technical assistance (RETA) 
grant. ADB’s policy on ANRR addresses three strategic objectives: (i) sustainable management 
of natural resources, (ii) increases in agricultural productivity, and (iii) poverty reduction. Eleven 
RETA grants have so far been approved, each supporting one or several projects of IARCs. The 
technical  assistance  (TA)  completion  reports  of  the  first  four  ANRR  RETAs  have  been 
completed and the draft TA completion reports for the fifth and sixth ANRR RETAs are being 
prepared. All RETAs have been rated as successful and the outcomes have strengthened 
knowledge products and technical agriculture research and extension operations in numerous 
developing member countries (DMCs), and have supported ADB’s operations in the agriculture 
and natural resources (ANR) sector. The IARCs work in virtually all of ADB’s DMCs, and several 
have their headquarters in Asian DMCs. 
 
2.  A special evaluation study2 of the ANRR policy carried out in 2000 recommended 
continued support to the IARCs, given the high returns on investments, relevance of the policy 
and research outputs of supported projects, and overall effectiveness of the annual RETA 
modality. While the ANRR policy specifies yearly ADB funding of $5.0 million to support ANRR, 
the support has been decreasing since 2000. It amounted to $3.0 million in 2003 and 2004, and 
$1.0 million in 2005 and 2006. The RETAs have played an integral role in fulfilling ADB’s 
operational objectives in participating DMCs. They have also addressed, in varying degrees, 
ADB’s overarching goal of poverty reduction and related priorities such as regional cooperation 
and sustainable environmental management. 
 
3.  The  proposed  RETA3  will  be  the  twelfth  RETA  on  ANRR.  Employing  the  criteria 
established in the Guidelines on Submission of Project Proposals4 for RETAs on ANRR, the 
regional directors of the agriculture, environment, and natural resources divisions; and the 
agriculture, natural resources, and social services division assessed the 20 concept notes that 
had been received by September 2007 for consideration under the twelfth RETA on ANRR. 
Project proposals were prioritized by level of preparation, links with ADB’s poverty reduction 
strategy, and relevance and synergy with ADB operations. Considering the total funds available 
for 2007, two proposals were selected for inclusion in the proposed RETA: (i) one submitted by 
the International Center for Agricultural Research in the Dry Areas (ICARDA), and (ii) another by 
the International Crops Research Institute for the Semi-Arid Tropics (ICRISAT). The two are 
expected to promote the development, application, and dissemination of scientific research on 
problems faced by poor farmer households in Asia. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  In September 2000, heads of state adopted the Millennium Declaration confirming their 
countries’ commitment to achieving the Millennium Development Goals, a set of eight quantified 
                                                 
1  For purposes of this technical assistance (TA), the international agricultural research centers are the International 
Center for Agricultural Research in the Dry Areas and the International Crops Research Institute for the Semi-Arid 
Tropics. 
2  ADB. 2000. Special Evaluation Study on the Policy Implementation and Impact of Agriculture and Natural 
Resources Research. Manila. 
3  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 17 November 2007. 
4  ADB. 2005. Guidelines for Project Proposal Submissions as Part of the Agriculture and Natural Resources 
Research at International Agricultural Research Centers. Manila.

2   
and specific time-bound targets for addressing the many dimensions of extreme poverty—from 
income poverty, hunger, health, education, environment, and gender. One of the Millennium 
Declaration’s most decisive goals, the first goal, aims at eradicating extreme poverty and hunger 
by reducing by half, between 1990 and 2015, the proportion of people living on less than $1 a 
day and of people suffering from hunger. 
 
5.  Despite  recent  progress,  especially  in  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC),  Asia 
continues to be home to two thirds of the world’s absolutely poor and food-insecure people. 
About 600 million people in Asia (down from 934 million in 1990) are absolutely poor, living on 
less than $1 a day.  Around 520 million (down from 570 million in 1990) lack sufficient access to 
food to lead healthy and productive lives. Given that the majority of poor people live in rural 
areas and rely on agriculture, and that agriculture paves the way for economic growth in poorer 
nations, the agriculture sector continues to underlie progress on the broad array of economic 
and social indicators emphasized by the Millennium Development Goals, in particular the first 
goal.5
 
6.  While 75% of the world’s poor live in rural areas in developing countries, a mere 4% of 
official development assistance goes to agriculture.6 Investing in ANRR is one of the most 
effective means of reducing poverty and stimulating agricultural and economic growth, through 
improvements  in  productivity.  A  recent  study  carried  out  a  comprehensive  survey  of  the 
literature on agricultural research since 1953 and statistically analyzed reported rates of return. 
Its  results  showed  that,  despite  wide  variability,  average  rates  of  return  are  very  high. 
Furthermore, the study found no evidence to support the view that rates of return have declined 
over time.7
 
7.  In Asia, one of the most urgent and rewarding area for research is to develop effective 
technologies,  institutions,  and  policies  to  deal  with  environmental  changes  due  to  land 
degradation and climate change. In Central Asia, the most important challenges facing the 
agriculture sector include depletion of soil nutrients, salinization, soil erosion, and other forms of 
land degradation. Recent estimates show that over 50% of irrigated soils in Central Asia are 
salinized or waterlogged. In many areas, policies to promote food security particularly through 
raising wheat production have promoted unsustainable agricultural production practices. In the 
semi-arid tropic regions of Asia, agriculture is highly vulnerable to climate change. Climate 
change is likely to make rain-fed agriculture even more risk-prone, and farmers and farming 
systems  will  need  to  adapt  to  these  changes.  However,  adaptation  by  vulnerable  and 
impoverished communities to new, evolving, and as yet uncertain climatic conditions in the 
future poses huge challenges.
 
8.  CGIAR, created in 1971, is a strategic alliance of countries, international and regional 
organizations, and private foundations supporting 15 IARCs that work with national agricultural 
research systems (NARS) and civil society organizations, including the private sector. It aims to 
achieve sustainable food security and reduce poverty through scientific agricultural research. 
CGIAR’s areas of focus are sustainable production, enhancing NARS, germplasm collection 
and improvement, and policy. CGIAR has been the driving force behind the Green Revolution. It 
has  spearheaded  international  agricultural  research  and  acted  as  the  focus  for  global 
                                                 
5  Rosegrant, Mark W., Claudia Ringler, Todd Benson, Xinshen Diao, Danielle Resnick, James Thurlow, Maximo 
Torero, and David Orden. 2005. Agriculture and Achieving the Millennium Development Goals. Washington, DC: 
Agriculture and Rural Development Department, World Bank, and IFPRI. 
6  World Bank. 2007. World Development Report 2008: Agriculture for Development. Washington, DC.  
7  Alston, Julian M., Connie Chan-Kang, Michele C. Marra, Philip G. Pardey, and T.J. Watt. 2000. A Meta-Analysis of 
Rates of Return to Agricultural R&D: Ex Pede Herculem? International Food Policy Research Institute Research 
Report 113. Washington, DC.

3
investment in research for development. A recent study on the benefits of CGIAR research 
against the cost of operating the whole system up to 2001 found that the value of documented 
benefits generated by CGIAR surpasses the total investment in the system even when analyzed 
from the most conservative perspective.8
 
9.  Most outcomes of agricultural research are of the public goods type and can be justified 
under grant financing. In Asia, ANRR has played an important role in promoting agricultural and 
rural development over the past 3 decades, and ADB as the key development institution in Asia 
has significant potential to further expand that role. Changes that ANRR has set in place have 
contributed to agricultural productivity increases and a reduction of poverty. According to the 
special evaluation study (footnote 2), ADB investments have paid large dividends. For the 
subset of projects assessed in the special evaluation study, the average internal rate of return 
for all funds invested in the projects was 65%.  
 
10.  The proposed RETA builds on the experience of previous ADB-funded RETAs on ANRR. 
It  notes  the  finding  of the  special  evaluation  study  that,  given  ADB’s  limited  resources  to 
contribute to ANRR, a focused agenda that more closely follows ADB’s overarching goal of 
poverty reduction is required. The design of the RETA also incorporates key lessons from  
previous RETAs, including the need for greater emphasis on (i) strengthening NARS capacity; 
(ii) improving linkages among researchers, practitioners, and policymakers to better disseminate 
research results; and (iii) strengthening ADB’s capacity to coordinate, supervise, monitor, and 
evaluate ANR activities. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The  proposed  RETA  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  policy  on  ANRR,  and  reinforces  the 
priorities outlined in ADB’s Medium-Term Strategy II and the Enhanced Poverty Reduction 
Strategy. The RETA aims at formulating, adopting, and implementing land degradation policies 
and strategies and reducing the vulnerability to climate change in the participating target DMCs. 
For purposes of Component 1, the target DMCs are PRC, Kazakhstan, the Kyrgyz Republic, 
Pakistan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan; for the purposes of Component 2, the 
target DMCs are Bangladesh, PRC, India, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka; Component 3 covers all 
DMCs. The outcome of the RETA is enhanced knowledge base and capacity in the participating 
DMCs to analyze the binding factors, and to recommend and formulate polices and strategies 
for  reducing  vulnerabilities  from  land  degradation  and  climate  change.  The  design  and 
monitoring framework of the RETA is in Appendix 1.  
  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The proposed RETA will have three components: (i) analysis of the existing land use 
policy, and institutional and environmental factors that influence land degradation; identification 
for  policy  options  to  support  the  adoption  of  improved  sustainable  land  management 
technologies that combat land degradation and improve productivity, and recommendation for 
conducive  policies  and  strategies  for  promoting  improved  development  pathways  and 
livelihoods based on sustainable land management; (ii) analysis of climate variability and its 
impact  on  cropping  pattern,  structures  of  income  and  employment,  and  adaptation-coping 
strategies of the rural poor, identification of best practices and institutional innovations for 
                                                 
8  Raitser, D.A. 2003. Benefit-Cost Meta-analysis of Investment in the International Agricultural Research Centers of 
the  Consultative  Group  on  International  Agricultural  Research.  Washington,  DC:  CGIAR  Science  Council 
Secretariat, and Rome: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations.

4   
mitigating  the  effects  of  climate  change,  and  recommendation  for  strategies  to  address 
socioeconomic problems relating to changing weather patterns and availability of a range of 
initiatives for their alleviation; and (iii) strengthening of ADB’s ANR capacity to coordinate, 
supervise, monitor, and evaluate ANR activities. The first two components have been identified 
in close consultation with participating DMCs,9 and will be implemented independently by two 
IARCs: ICARDA and ICRISAT. The last component will support ANR activities within ADB by (i) 
strengthening in-house ANR capacities and networks, (ii) organizing ANR seminars, and (iii) 
supporting small-scale agriculture and natural resources sector analysis. A summary of ADB’s 
assistance to IARCs, including CGIAR, is in Appendix 2. The synopses of the components are 
in paras. 13–17, and the detailed project descriptions are in Appendix 3.  
 
13.  Component  1.  Enabling  Policy  Options  for  Sustainable  Land  Management  in 
Central Asia, PRC, and Pakistan. Through the adoption and application within the national 
development  programs  of  the  recommended  policies  that  promote  sustainable  land 
management  practices,  the  proposed  component  will  assist  in  restoring,  maintaining,  and 
enhancing  land  productivity  in  PRC,  Kazakhstan,  Kyrgyz  Republic,  Pakistan,  Tajikistan, 
Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan.  
 
14.  Key activities will include (i) analyzing the existing land use policy, and institutional and 
environmental factors that influence land degradation; (ii) supporting the adoption of improved 
sustainable  land  management  technologies  that  combat  land  degradation  and  improve 
productivity; and (iii) developing recommendations for conducive policy options and strategies 
for  promoting  improved  development  pathways  and  livelihood,  based  on  sustainable  land 
management. 
 
15.  Component 2. Vulnerability to Climate Change: Adaptation Strategies and Layers 
of Resilience. The proposed component will provide science-based solutions and pro-poor 
approaches for adapting agricultural systems to climate change for the rural poor and most 
vulnerable farmers in semi-arid regions of Asia, particularly Bangladesh, PRC, India, Pakistan, 
and Sri Lanka. It will identify and prioritize the sectors most at risk and develop gender-equitable 
agricultural adaptation and mitigation strategies as an integral part of agricultural development 
in these less-favored areas. Component 2 will cover innovations in agricultural institutions, the 
role of women, social capital, and social networks. 
 
16.  Key activities comprise (i) seeking an improved understanding of climate variability and 
its impact on cropping patterns, structures of income and employment, and adaptation-coping 
strategies of the rural poor in the semi-arid tropic villages; (ii) promoting best practices and 
institutional  innovations  for  mitigating  the  effects  of  climate  change;  and  (iii)  formulating 
strategies  to  address  socioeconomic  problems  relating  to  changing  weather  patterns  and 
examining a range of initiatives for their alleviation. 
 
17.  Component  3.  Developing  Capacity  for  ANR-Related  Activities.  The  project 
responds to the key lesson and needs identified so as to enhance ADB’s in-house capacity to 
effectively coordinate, supervise, monitor, evaluate, and strengthen ANR activities and networks 
with CGIAR and other non-CGIAR IARCs. The proposed component will establish an ANR 
secretariat and provide support to ADB’s in-house ANR activities including reports, conferences, 
seminars, publication, dissemination, and networking as well as small-scale agriculture and 
natural resources sector analysis. ADB’s ANR focal point in the East Asia Department will take 
                                                 
9  A no-objection letter has been sent to each participating DMC to obtain its concurrence. No-objection letters will be 
obtained in each DMC as a condition to ADB financing under the TA.

5
the lead in planning and organizing these activities in consultation with concerned regional 
departments.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The total cost of the RETA is estimated at $2.863 million equivalent. ADB will finance 
$2.000 million, comprising $0.775 million for Component 1, $1.100 million for Component 2, and 
$0.125 million for Component 3. The financing will be on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding 
program. With respect to component 1, ICARDA will contribute $0.227 million equivalent in kind 
in the form of staff time and administrative and support costs over 3 years; and the governments 
of PRC, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan, 
through NARS, will together provide $0.126 million equivalent in kind, in the form of staff time, 
administration  and  support  costs,  office  facilities,  transport,  and  research  operations  and 
supplies over 3 years as well. With respect to component 2, ICRISAT will contribute $0.260 
million equivalent in kind in the form of staff time and administrative and support costs over 3 
years; and the governments of Bangladesh, PRC, India, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka, through 
NARS, will together provide $0.250 million equivalent in kind in the form of staff time, office 
equipment,  training  and  workshops,  surveys  and  database  development,  information 
dissemination, and administrative support over 3 years as well. The detailed cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 4. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The RETA will follow the implementation arrangements used in previous ADB-financed 
RETAs for ANRR. ADB will enter into separate TA agreements with each IARC. Each executing 
agency (EA) will be responsible for implementing and completing its own component. ICARDA, 
through its head office in Damascus, Syria, and in partnership with the International Food Policy 
Research Institute, will be the EA for Component 1. ICRISAT, with its head office in Andhra 
Pradesh, India, will be the EA for Component 2. The 10 participating NARS10 will be designated 
as the implementing agencies (IAs), and will collaborate closely with the IARCs. Each EA will 
appoint a project team coordinator, either a current IARC staff or externally recruited consultants, 
who will coordinate, plan, and supervise all local project activities; monitor project progress; and 
submit required reports to ADB and other collaborating partners. Similarly, each IA will appoint a 
country team coordinator who will be responsible for coordinating, implementing, and reporting 
on the project activities.  
 
20.  The RETA is expected to start in January 2008 and be completed in December 2010. 
ICARDA and ICRISAT will start to implement the TA after ADB’s satisfactory review of the 
detailed work program including staffing to ensure close coordination with other related ongoing 
programs and partners at the provincial and national levels in the participating countries. Each 
project will hold an inception workshop within 3 months after it starts, to firm up project plans 
and implementation arrangements with partners. Each IARC will also organize annual planning 
and review meetings and a project completion workshop that all project partners, including ADB, 
will attend. Each IARC must submit the following reports to ADB: (i) an inception report; (ii) 
semiannual progress reports; (iii) semiannual financial statements accounting for the use of 
                                                 
10 The 10 national agricultural research systems are (i) Center for Policy Dialogue in Bangladesh; (ii) Central 
  Research Institute for Dryland Agriculture in India; (iii) Kazakh Research Institute of Soil Sciences in Kazakhstan; 
  (iv) Kyrgyz Research Institute of Agriculture in Kyrgyz Republic; (v) Pakistan Agricultural Research Council in 
  Pakistan; (vi) Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences in the PRC; (vii) Council for Agricultural Research Policy 
  in Sri Lanka; (viii) Tajik Research Institute of Soil Sciences in Tajikistan; (ix) National Institute of Deserts, Flora, and 
  Fauna in Turkmenistan; and (x) Central Asian Research Institute of Irrigation in Uzbekistan.

6   
project funds; (iv) audited annual financial statements, including the use of project funds; and (v) 
a draft final completion report to obtain ADB comments before the final report is submitted. The 
inception  reports  will  be  submitted  within  3  months  of  the  start  of  each  component;  the 
semiannual progress reports and financial statements, every 6 months; and the comprehensive 
completion report, within 3 months of project closure. Funds will be drawn down in semiannual 
installments  based  on  each  IARC’s  estimate  of  forthcoming  expenditures,  and  subject  to 
satisfactory  liquidation  of  expenditures  for  previously  disbursed  funds.  Project  officers  with 
suitable technical expertise will be assigned to administer the components at ADB, and will 
undertake at least one supervisory mission yearly to each component.  
 
21.  The participating IARCs will procure goods and related services in accordance with 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (as amended from time to time) and will engage consultants in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (as amended from time to time) 
and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB. At the end of each project, equipment purchased 
under the RETA will be assigned to the EA and IAs concerned. Disbursement under the RETA 
will be undertaken in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Disbursement of TA Grants (as 
amended from time to time). 
 
22.  The IARCs have made plans for disseminating the outputs and evaluating the outcome. 
The outputs will be published in academic journals, books, and reports as well as posted on 
IARCs’  websites  and  ADB  websites.  A  comprehensive  media  dissemination  plan  will  be 
developed during TA implementation. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
23.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 on a grant basis for the Twelfth Agriculture and 
Natural Resources Research at International Agricultural Research Centers.

•  identification of the role of social institutions, social capital, and social networks in 
adaptation processes and practices (by Q2, 2009)  
•  mapping of alternate channels and institutional arrangements for strategies and 
mechanisms to mitigate the effects of climate change (by Q1, 2010)   
•  study of the effects of policy changes and institutional innovations on cropping 
patterns and productivity levels (by Q1, 2010) 
Output 2.3  
•  collection of data on farm and nonfarm enterprises (by Q2, 2009)  
•  analysis of data and assessment of the viability of alternative enterprises (by Q2, 
2010) 
•  assessment of the optimum mix of farm and nonfarm enterprises to maximize the 
returns to fixed factors and to minimize risk (by Q3, 2010)  
•  preparation of policy briefs and workshops to advocate the necessary policy 
changes (by Q4, 2010)  
•  impact analysis of alternative investment options to help farmers adapt to shocks 
resulting from weather aberrations (by Q4, 2010) 
 
Component 3 
Output 3.1  
•  establishment of an ANR secretariat (by Q2, 2008) 
•  support  to  ADB’s  in-house  ANR  activities  including  reports,  conferences, 
seminars, publication, dissemination and networking (by Q2, 2008) 
•  support to small-scale agriculture and natural resource sector analysis (by Q4, 
2008) 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, ANR = agriculture and natural resources, CGIAR = Consultative Group on International

20  Appendix 3 
TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR REGIONAL TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE OUTPUTS 
 
  
A.  Component 1. Enabling Policy Options for Sustainable Land Management in Central 
Asia, Pakistan, and People’s Republic of China (PRC) with the International Center 
for Agricultural Research in the Dry Areas (ICARDA)  
 
  1.  Introduction  
 
1.  The component aims to restore, maintain, and enhance the productive functions of land in 
PRC,  Kazakhstan,  Kyrgyz  Republic,  Pakistan,  Tajikistan,  Turkmenistan,  and  Uzbekistan.  The 
result will be the improved economic and social well-being of those who depend on land and its 
resources and, at the same time, the preservation of the environmental functions of those lands. 
The  outcome  of  the  component  will  be  the  adoption  and  application  within  the  national 
development programs of the recommended policies that promote sustainable land management 
practices.  
 
2.  Three outputs are expected from the component: (i) analysis of the existing land use policy, 
and institutional and environmental factors that influence land degradation; (ii) identified policy 
options  to  support  the  adoption  of  improved  sustainable  land  management  technologies  that 
combat land degradation and improve productivity; and (iii) recommended policies and strategies 
for  promoting  improved  development  pathways  and  livelihood  based  on  sustainable  land 
management.  
 
3.  Key activities associated with the first output will include (i) collection of secondary and 
primary  data  required  for  analysis;  (ii)  analysis  of  the  status  of  land  degradation  in  PRC, 
Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan using relevant 
indicators with focus on soil erosion, salinity, waterlogging, and depletion of soil nutrients; and (iii) 
analysis of the existing policies, policy objectives, and environment, and assessment of the impact 
of existing policies on land degradation.  
 
4.  Key activities associated with the second output will include (i) a review of the existing 
projects on land degradation in selected countries to identify policy gaps and develop mechanisms 
for  mainstreaming  the  policy  options  developed  by  the  research  project;  (ii)  analysis  of  the 
improved land management technologies introduced by past and ongoing Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) regional technical assistance projects; and (iii) identification of enabling institutional 
and policy alternatives to promote adoption of those technologies.  
 
5.  Key  activities  associated  with  the  third  output  will  include  (i)  integrated  systems  and 
situation analysis for each country; (ii) development of recommendations for policy options and 
strategies for promoting improved development pathways and livelihood based on sustainable land 
management; and (iii) policy consultation meetings, dialogue, and communication of the study 
findings to all stakeholders. 
 
2.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
6.  ICARDA in partnership with the International Food Policy Research Institute will be the 
Executing  Agency  (EA)  for  Component  1.  ICARDA  and  International  Food  Policy  Research 
Institute will jointly recruit and appoint a project team coordinator who will undertake the research, 
with oversight from senior researchers in the two centers. The implementing agencies (IAs) are the 
following national agricultural research systems (NARS): (i) Kazakh Research Institute of Soil

Appendix 3        21 
Sciences in Kazakhstan; (ii) Kyrgyz Research Institute of Agriculture in Kyrgyz Republic; (iii) Tajik 
Research Institute of Soil Sciences in Tajikistan; (iv) National Institute of Deserts, Flora, and Fauna 
in Turkmenistan; (v) Central Asian Research Institute of Irrigation in Uzbekistan; (vi) Chinese 
Academy of Agricultural Sciences in the PRC; and (vii) Pakistan Agricultural Research Council in 
Pakistan. 
 
7.  Component 1 will be implemented over 3 years, from January 2008 to December 2010. A 
detailed work plan will be developed during the inception workshop. Each collaborating NARS will 
delegate a project coordinator for the component, who will coordinate the input of national teams. A 
steering committee, comprising representatives from all partners, will meet each year to evaluate 
the  progress  of  the  component.  ADB  will  have  observer  status.  Coordination  and  planning 
meetings will be organized annually to review annual progress, develop work plans, respond to 
emerging constraints, ensure active participation of policymakers, and enhance integration among 
the participating countries. A completion workshop will be held to review project achievements and 
communicate these to policymakers and other stakeholders. 
 
8.  ICARDA  will  start  implementing  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  after  ADB’s  satisfactory 
review of the detailed work program including staffing to ensure close coordination with related 
programs including the ongoing Central Asian Countries Initiatives for Land Management. ICARDA 
is also expected to coordinate with partner organizations at provincial and national levels in the 
target developing member countries (DMCs). ICARDA will be required to submit the following 
reports to ADB: (i) inception report; (ii) semiannual technical progress reports; (iii) semiannual 
financial statements accounting for the use of funds; (iv) audited annual financial statements, 
including the use of funds; and (v) a draft final completion report to obtain ADB’s comments before 
the final report is submitted. The inception report will be prepared within 3 months of TA inception 
and will be discussed and finalized at the inception planning workshop. Semiannual technical 
progress  reports  and  financial  statements  will  be  submitted  every  6  months,  and  the 
comprehensive completion report will be submitted within 3 months of project closure. Funds will 
be  drawn  down  in  semiannual  installments  based  on  ICARDA’s  estimate  of  forthcoming 
expenditures, and subject to satisfactory liquidation of expenditures for previously disbursed funds. 
 
9.  ICARDA  will  engage  consultants  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (as amended from time to time) and other agreements satisfactory to ADB, and will 
procure goods and services in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (as amended from 
time to time).  
 
B.  Component 2. Vulnerability to Climate Change: Adaptation Strategies and Layers of 
Resilience with the International Crops Research Institute for the Semi-Arid Tropics 
(ICRISAT)  
 
  1.  Introduction  
 
10.  Component  2  aims  to  provide  science-based  solutions  and  pro-poor  approaches  for 
adapting agricultural systems to climate change for the rural poor and most vulnerable farmers in 
semi-arid regions of Asia,  especially  Bangladesh, PRC, India, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka. The 
outcome will be to identify and prioritize the sectors most at risk and develop gender-equitable 
agricultural adaptation and mitigation strategies as an integral part of agricultural development in 
these less-favored areas.  The outcome will cover innovations in agricultural institutions, the role of 
women, social capital, and social networks.

22  Appendix 3 
11.  The outputs of Component 2 will include (i) an improved understanding of climate variability 
and its impact on cropping patterns, structures of income and employment, and adaptation-coping 
strategies of the rural poor; (ii) best practices and institutional innovations for mitigating the effects 
of climate change; and (iii) strategies to address socioeconomic problems relating to changing 
weather patterns and a range of initiatives for their alleviation. 
 
12.  The  key  activities  to  achieve  the first  output will  include  (i)  collection  and  analysis  of 
secondary  data  on  weather  parameters,  and  on  cropping  patterns,  incomes,  employment, 
consumption levels, enterprise economics, etc., from the target DMCs; (ii) survey and comparison 
of farmers’ perceptions about climate change and variability; (iii) adaptation of suitable simulation 
models  to  determine  relationships  between  weather  parameters,  cropping  patterns,  and 
productivity and income levels; (iv) documentation of the changes related to climate variability; and 
(v) report on the cause-effect relationships between changes in cropping patterns and productivity 
levels on one hand, and  changes in the weather parameters, length of growing period, policy 
changes, and institutional innovations on the other, employing appropriate statistical tools.  
 
13.  The key activities for the second output will include (i) assessment and analysis of past and 
present adaptation practices using a social lens to identify what works and what does not; (ii) 
identifying the role of social institutions, social capital, and social networks in adaptation processes 
and practices; (iii) mapping alternate channels and institutional arrangements for strategies and 
mechanisms to mitigate the effects of climate change; and (iv) study and report on the cause-effect 
relationships between changes in cropping patterns and productivity levels on one hand, and 
changes in the weather parameters, length of growing period, policy changes, and institutional 
innovations on the other, employing appropriate statistical tools. 
 
14.  The key activities for the third output will include (i)  collecting data on supplementary farm 
and nonfarm enterprises from a sample of households in target locations; (ii) analyzing data using 
economic tools, and assessing the viability of alternative enterprises; (iii) assessing the optimum 
mix of farm and nonfarm enterprises to maximize the returns to fixed factors and to minimize the 
risk; (iv) preparing policy briefs and conducting policy workshops to advocate the necessary policy 
changes to reduce poverty and the impact of income shocks caused by weather aberrations; and 
(v) analyzing the impact of alternative investment options to help farmers adapt to shocks resulting 
from weather aberrations. 
 
2.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ICRISAT will be the EA for Component 2. The IAs are the following NARS: (i) Central 
Research Institute for Dryland Agriculture in India, (ii) Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences in 
the PRC, (iii) Center for Policy Dialogue in Bangladesh, (iv) Council for Agricultural Research 
Policy in Sri Lanka, and (v) Pakistan Agricultural Research Council in Pakistan. ICRISAT will 
appoint a project team coordinator from among its staff. The collaborating NARS will also appoint a 
country team coordinator for its component of the work. Research subcontracts will be signed 
between ICRISAT and the target DMCs. 
 
16.  Component 2 will be implemented over 3 years, from January 2008 to December 2010. A 
monitoring  and  evaluation  system  will  be  established,  using  a  metric  approach,  whereby 
quantifiable  indicators  will  be  used  to  measure  progress.  The  quantifiable  indicators  will  be 
augmented by qualitative indicators of impact. A detailed work plan will be developed during the 
inception workshop that will take place within 3 months of the start of the component. The steering 
committee formed under the component will continue to be operational. The EA will also organize 
annual planning and review meetings and a completion workshop in the third quarter of the third

Appendix 3        23 
year, which will be attended by all partners and ADB. The workshop will recommend sustainable 
approaches to ensure the continuity of the improvement programs that will have been initiated. 
 
17.  ICRISAT will start implementing the TA after ADB’s satisfactory review of the detailed work 
program including staffing to ensure close coordination with related ongoing programs. ICRISAT  is 
also expected to coordinate with partner organizations at provincial and national levels in the 
participating  countries.  ICRISAT  will  be  required  to  submit  the  following  reports  to  ADB:  (i) 
inception report; (ii) semiannual technical progress reports; (iii) semiannual financial statements 
accounting for the use of funds; (iv) audited annual financial statements, including the use of funds; 
and (v) a draft final completion report to obtain ADB comments before the final report is submitted. 
The inception report will be prepared within 3 months of TA inception and will be discussed and 
finalized at the inception planning workshop. Semiannual technical progress reports and financial 
statements will be submitted every 6 months, and the comprehensive completion report will be 
submitted within 3 months of project closure. Funds will be drawn down in semiannual installments 
based on ICRISAT’s estimate of forthcoming expenditures, and subject to satisfactory liquidation of 
expenditures for previously disbursed funds.  
 
18.  ICRISAT will engage consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (as amended from time to time) and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB, and will 
procure goods and services in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (as amended from 
time to time). 
 
C.  Component 3. Developing Capacity for Agriculture and Natural Resources (ANR)-
  Related Activities  
 
  1.  Introduction  
 
19.  Component 3 aims to strengthen ADB’s in-house capacity to coordinate, supervise, monitor, 
and evaluate ANR activities by establishing a secretariat in the Agriculture, Environment, and 
Natural Resources Division of the East Asia Department of ADB for more effective collaboration 
and  information  exchange  among  regional  divisions  and  Consultative  Group  on  International 
Agricultural  Research  (CGIAR)  and  non-CGIAR  international  agricultural  research  centers  in 
agriculture sector planning, and research and development, in collaboration with other such ANR- 
related activities within ADB including the secretariat for the Greater Mekong Subregion. The 
component will support agriculture, environment, natural resource sector studies, and capacity 
development activities such as workshops and seminars on agriculture and natural resources 
research to promote information flow among staff of the agriculture, environment, and natural 
resources divisions in ADB. The component will also finance national and international consultants 
including an ANR focal point coordinator to provide technical services including ANR focal point 
support  during  implementation,  and  finance  the  preparation  of  ANR  reports,  publication,  and 
dissemination of produced materials. The secretariat will also enhance information sharing among 
other ANR-related initiatives within ADB including the working group on agriculture secretariat for 
the Greater Mekong Subregion countries and other such forums at regional and country office 
levels. 
 
  2.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  Component 3 will be implemented over 12 months, from January 2008 to December 2008. 
ADB will be the EA and IA for the component. Within ADB, the Agriculture, Environment and 
Natural Resources Division of the East Asia Regional Department will be responsible for ANR focal 
point activities. An ANR secretariat will be established to coordinate and administer the activities 
for this component.

information and knowledge
